ROLE
You are an expert software planner–builder inside a code IDE with file system and terminal access.
Your job is to:
(1) clarify with me the technology stack and constraints from a tech-agnostic PRD,
(2) generate a clear, ordered checklist of tasks in markdown, and
(3) iteratively execute and tick them off as you go.

CRITICAL GUARDRAILS
- Never reveal your private chain-of-thought. Use internal scratchpads for reasoning.
- No secrets in code. Use `.env.example` for configuration.
- If something is unclear, create targeted questions in `docs/QUESTIONS.md` and stop until clarified.

INPUTS
<PRD>
The PRD document should be studied carefully. It should be contained in the current working directory. If not, the user should be prompted to provide it.
</PRD>

<CONSTRAINTS_AND_PREFERENCES> (optional but recommended)
- Coding standards, licensing, hosting, performance, etc.
- This product is a **web application**.
- Use structured logging on the server (e.g., pino/winston) and sanitize PII.

OBJECTIVES
1) Clarify stack for a web application: ask for options for Frontend, Backend, Data, Auth, Testing. Record rationale in `docs/DECISIONS.md`. Ask one clarification at a time. One question at a time.
   - If unclear → also write `docs/QUESTIONS.md` and stop until answered.

2) Create tasks: Write `plans/TASKS.md` as a simple checklist derived from the PRD context. Keep each item a short, verifiable one-liner. Example:

```markdown
# Project Task Plan (Web)

## Setup
- [ ] Initialize repo with README, license, .gitignore, .editorconfig
- [ ] Create `.env.example` and document required vars
- [ ] Configure formatter + linter (e.g., Prettier/ESLint)
- [ ] Set up minimal CI (lint, typecheck, tests)

## Architecture & Scaffolding
- [ ] Choose stack and write `docs/DECISIONS.md`
- [ ] Scaffold backend (e.g., Node/TypeScript or chosen framework)
- [ ] Scaffold frontend (e.g., React/Vue or chosen framework)
- [ ] Add shared types/interfaces

## Backend (Web)
- [ ] Define API routes and handlers
- [ ] Implement core domain endpoints
- [ ] Add data layer (ORM/queries) and migrations
- [ ] Add input validation and error handling
- [ ] Seed sample data (if applicable)

## Frontend (Web)
- [ ] Configure routing and layout shell
- [ ] Implement authentication UI
- [ ] Build core pages/views from PRD
- [ ] Wire API calls and state management
- [ ] Add accessible components and basic a11y checks

## Security & Auth
- [ ] Implement chosen auth strategy (e.g., session/JWT/OAuth)
- [ ] Protect routes and enforce RBAC/permissions
- [ ] Add security headers and basic rate limiting

## Observability
- [ ] Add structured logging (server)
- [ ] Add basic metrics/tracing hooks (if available)
- [ ] Add client error/reporting hook

## QA & Performance
- [ ] Add unit tests for core modules
- [ ] Add API integration tests
- [ ] Add frontend component/feature tests
- [ ] Add basic performance budgets/checks

## Docs & Ops
- [ ] Update `README` with setup/run scripts
- [ ] Add `docs/ASSUMPTIONS.md`
- [ ] Add `docs/BUILD_LOG.md` (initialized)
- [ ] Add deployment scripts/manifests (as applicable)

Each task should be small, testable, and can be ticked off (- [x]) when complete.

Execution loop: 

- Pick next unchecked task. 
- Implement it in code. 
- Run lint/tests. 
- If successful, tick off in plans/TASKS.md and append to docs/BUILD_LOG.md with timestamp + short summary. 
- Commit with Conventional Commits style (feat:, fix:, etc.). 
- If blocked → add question to docs/QUESTIONS.md and leave the checkbox unchecked with a short note.

OUTPUT RULES

- First output: either 
a) “STACK DECISION PROPOSAL” with questions → stop, OR 
b) Create plans/TASKS.md, docs/DECISIONS.md, docs/ASSUMPTIONS.md, and empty docs/BUILD_LOG.md. 
- Then proceed task by task, updating the checklist. 
- Keep the checklist readable, concise, and fully auditable in git history. 

BEGIN.

1→# Product Requirements Document (PRD)
     2→## MagnaPP Web Application
     3→
     4→---
     5→
     6→## 1. Introduction & Overview
     7→
     8→### 1.1 Product Name
     9→**MagnaPP** (Agile Planning Poker Platform)
    10→
    11→### 1.2 Problem Statement
    12→Distributed agile development teams need an effective way to conduct Planning Poker estimation sessions remotely. Current solutions often lack real-time collaboration features or provide poor user experiences that hinder the estimation process.
    13→
    14→### 1.3 Solution Overview
    15→MagnaPP is a web-based Planning Poker application that enables multiple users to participate in real-time estimation sessions through a virtual boardroom interface. The application provides seamless collaboration with immediate visual feedback, session management, and reconnection capabilities.
    16→
    17→### 1.4 Success Vision
    18→Teams can easily create and join MagnaPP sessions, conduct multiple estimation rounds efficiently, and maintain engagement through an intuitive virtual boardroom experience.
    19→
    20→---
    21→
    22→## 2. Goals & Objectives
    23→
    24→### 2.1 Primary Goals
    25→- Enable real-time collaborative Planning Poker sessions for up to 16 users
    26→- Provide an intuitive virtual boardroom experience that mimics in-person sessions
    27→- Ensure seamless user experience across desktop and mobile devices
    28→- Minimize setup time and technical barriers for users
    29→
    30→### 2.2 Success Metrics
    31→- Session completion rate: >95% of started sessions complete at least one voting round
    32→- User retention: Users who join a session stay for the full duration >90% of the time
    33→- Reconnection success: >98% of disconnected users successfully rejoin their session
    34→- Cross-device functionality: Application works seamlessly on desktop and mobile
    35→
    36→---
    37→
    38→## 3. Target Audience & User Personas
    39→
    40→### 3.1 Primary Users
    41→**Agile Development Teams** (3-16 members)
    42→- Scrum Masters, Product Owners, Developers, QA Engineers
    43→- Teams working remotely or in hybrid environments
    44→- Organizations using agile methodologies (Scrum, SAFe, etc.)
    45→
    46→### 3.2 User Personas
    47→
    48→#### Persona 1: Sarah - Scrum Master
    49→- **Role**: Facilitates MagnaPP sessions
    50→- **Goals**: Run efficient estimation sessions, maintain team engagement, keep discussions focused
    51→- **Pain Points**: Coordinating remote team members, ensuring everyone participates
    52→- **Technical Comfort**: High
    53→
    54→#### Persona 2: Mike - Developer
    55→- **Role**: Participates in estimation sessions
    56→- **Goals**: Provide accurate estimates, understand story requirements
    57→- **Pain Points**: Connection issues disrupting flow, unclear voting status
    58→- **Technical Comfort**: High
    59→
    60→#### Persona 3: Lisa - Product Owner
    61→- **Role**: Participates in estimation, provides clarification
    62→- **Goals**: Ensure team understands requirements, get reliable estimates
    63→- **Pain Points**: Difficulty seeing who has voted, losing session context
    64→- **Technical Comfort**: Medium
    65→
    66→---
    67→
    68→## 4. User Stories & Use Cases
    69→
    70→### 4.1 Epic 1: User Registration & Session Access
    71→
    72→#### User Story 1.1: Initial User Setup
    73→**As a** new user  
    74→**I want to** enter my name/alias and choose an avatar  
    75→**So that** I can be identified in MagnaPP sessions  
    76→
    77→**Acceptance Criteria:**
    78→- User must enter a name/alias (minimum 2 characters, maximum 50 characters)
    79→- User can select from available icon library for avatar
    80→- User settings are stored in browser local storage
    81→- Settings persist across browser sessions
    82→- Name validation prevents empty, whitespace-only, or special character names
    83→
    84→#### User Story 1.2: Session Creation
    85→**As a** Scrum Master  
    86→**I want to** create a new MagnaPP session  
    87→**So that** my team can join and participate in estimation  
    88→
    89→**Acceptance Criteria:**
    90→- User can enter session name (required, 3-100 characters)
    91→- System generates unique GUID for session ID
    92→- System provides shareable link for the session
    93→- User becomes Scrum Master with full session control
    94→- Session is created in application memory
    95→- Session expiry timer starts at 10 minutes of inactivity
    96→
    97→#### User Story 1.3: Session Discovery
    98→**As a** user  
    99→**I want to** browse existing active sessions  
   100→**So that** I can join a session without needing a direct link  
   101→
   102→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   103→- Display list of active sessions with names only
   104→- Show sessions sorted by creation time (newest first)
   105→- Allow user to select and join any active session
   106→- Update list dynamically as sessions are created/expire
   107→- Handle empty state when no sessions exist
   108→
   109→#### User Story 1.4: Direct Session Joining
   110→**As a** team member  
   111→**I want to** join a session using a shared link  
   112→**So that** I can quickly access the MagnaPP session  
   113→
   114→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   115→- Link format: `/session/{GUID}`
   116→- If user has saved settings, auto-populate name/avatar
   117→- If no saved settings, prompt for name/alias entry before joining
   118→- Validate session exists and is active
   119→- Handle expired or invalid session links with appropriate error message
   120→- Redirect to session boardroom upon successful join
   121→
   122→### 4.2 Epic 2: Session Management
   123→
   124→#### User Story 2.1: Scrum Master Controls
   125→**As a** Scrum Master  
   126→**I want to** control the MagnaPP session flow  
   127→**So that** I can facilitate effective estimation discussions  
   128→
   129→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   130→- Can start a new voting round for all participants
   131→- Can reveal all votes simultaneously
   132→- Can start a new round (resets all votes and voting status)
   133→- Can end the session (returns all users to home screen)
   134→- Can kick users from the session
   135→- Can transfer Scrum Master role to another participant
   136→- All actions are immediately reflected to all session participants
   137→
   138→#### User Story 2.2: Session Inactivity Management
   139→**As a** system administrator  
   140→**I want** sessions to expire after inactivity  
   141→**So that** system resources are managed efficiently  
   142→
   143→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   144→- Session expires after 10 minutes of no user activity
   145→- Warning timer appears when 2 minutes remain
   146→- All users see the countdown timer
   147→- Expired sessions are removed from memory
   148→- Users in expired sessions are redirected to home screen
   149→- Activity includes: voting, revealing votes, starting new rounds, user joins/leaves
   150→
   151→#### User Story 2.3: Scrum Master Disconnection Handling
   152→**As a** session participant  
   153→**I want** the session to wait for Scrum Master reconnection  
   154→**So that** we don't lose session control or progress  
   155→
   156→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   157→- When Scrum Master disconnects, session enters "paused" state
   158→- All participants see "Waiting for Scrum Master to return" message
   159→- Session controls are disabled for all users
   160→- Scrum Master can reconnect and resume session within timeout period
   161→- If Scrum Master doesn't return within 5 minutes, longest-connected user becomes new Scrum Master
   162→- Automatic role transfer is announced to all participants
   163→
   164→### 4.3 Epic 3: Virtual Boardroom Experience
   165→
   166→#### User Story 3.1: Boardroom Visualization
   167→**As a** session participant  
   168→**I want to** see all users arranged around a virtual table  
   169→**So that** I have a familiar meeting room experience  
   170→
   171→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   172→- Users displayed as avatars around an oval table
   173→- Maximum 16 user positions around the table
   174→- Avatar shows icon selected by user
   175→- Username displayed below avatar
   176→- Users positioned randomly around table when joining
   177→- Scrum Master has visual indicator (crown icon or similar)
   178→- Responsive layout works on desktop, tablet, and mobile
   179→
   180→#### User Story 3.2: Voting Status Indicators
   181→**As a** session participant  
   182→**I want to** see who has voted in the current round  
   183→**So that** I know the voting progress without seeing actual votes  
   184→
   185→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   186→- Each user has a visual indicator showing voted/not voted status
   187→- Green indicator for "has voted"
   188→- Red indicator for "not voted" (only during active voting)
   189→- No indicator when not in voting round
   190→- Indicators update in real-time as users submit votes
   191→- My own vote is visible to me but not to others until reveal
   192→
   193→### 4.4 Epic 4: Voting Process
   194→
   195→#### User Story 4.1: Voting Round Initiation
   196→**As a** Scrum Master  
   197→**I want to** start a voting round  
   198→**So that** all team members can submit their estimates  
   199→
   200→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   201→- "Start Voting" button visible only to Scrum Master
   202→- Button disabled during active voting or when results are shown
   203→- Clicking starts voting round for all participants
   204→- All users immediately see voting cards interface
   205→- Audio notification plays for all users when voting starts
   206→- Voting status indicators reset for all users
   207→
   208→#### User Story 4.2: Vote Submission
   209→**As a** session participant  
   210→**I want to** select my estimate using voting cards  
   211→**So that** I can participate in the estimation process  
   212→
   213→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   214→- Voting cards display Fibonacci sequence: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21
   215→- Additional "Coffee" card for break requests
   216→- Cards are visually distinct and clickable
   217→- Selected card is highlighted/emphasized
   218→- Can change vote until Scrum Master reveals votes
   219→- My vote appears next to my avatar (visible only to me)
   220→- Audio feedback when card is selected
   221→- Vote is immediately saved and status indicator updates
   222→
   223→#### User Story 4.3: Vote Revelation
   224→**As a** Scrum Master  
   225→**I want to** reveal all votes simultaneously  
   226→**So that** we can discuss estimates and reach consensus  
   227→
   228→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   229→- "Reveal Votes" button visible only to Scrum Master
   230→- Button enabled only when at least one vote is submitted
   231→- All votes revealed simultaneously across all clients
   232→- Vote cards "flip over" next to each user's avatar to show their vote
   233→- Vote statistics panel appears showing average and distribution
   234→- Audio notification plays when votes are revealed
   235→- Voting cards interface is hidden during results display
   236→
   237→#### User Story 4.4: Vote Statistics
   238→**As a** session participant  
   239→**I want to** see voting statistics after revelation  
   240→**So that** I can understand the team's estimation consensus  
   241→
   242→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   243→- Display average of numeric votes (excluding Coffee votes)
   244→- Show vote distribution (count of each vote value)
   245→- Indicate consensus when all votes are identical
   246→- Coffee votes counted separately
   247→- Statistics update automatically when votes are revealed
   248→- Visual representation (simple bar chart or similar) for distribution
   249→
   250→### 4.5 Epic 5: Connection Management
   251→
   252→#### User Story 5.1: User Reconnection
   253→**As a** session participant  
   254→**I want to** rejoin my session after losing connection  
   255→**So that** I can continue participating without disruption  
   256→
   257→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   258→- User can rejoin session using same name/avatar
   259→- Rejoined user sees current session state (voting round, results, etc.)
   260→- If voting in progress and user had voted, show their previous vote
   261→- If voting in progress and user hadn't voted, allow them to vote
   262→- Other participants see reconnection notification
   263→- User resumes at their previous position around the table
   264→
   265→#### User Story 5.2: Real-time Synchronization
   266→**As a** session participant  
   267→**I want** all session changes to appear immediately  
   268→**So that** I have a seamless collaborative experience  
   269→
   270→**Acceptance Criteria:**
   271→- All user actions sync in real-time (<1 second delay)
   272→- Vote submissions immediately update voting indicators
   273→- Scrum Master actions (start voting, reveal votes) appear instantly
   274→- User joins/leaves reflect immediately in boardroom
   275→- Session state maintained consistently across all clients
   276→- Connection status visible to users (connected/reconnecting indicator)
   277→
   278→---
   279→
   280→## 5. Functional Requirements
   281→
   282→### 5.1 User Management
   283→- **FR-1.1**: System shall allow users to set name/alias (2-50 characters, alphanumeric and spaces only)
   284→- **FR-1.2**: System shall provide icon selection for user avatars
   285→- **FR-1.3**: System shall store user preferences in browser storage with 30-day expiration
   286→- **FR-1.4**: System shall validate user input and provide appropriate error messages
   287→
   288→### 5.2 Session Management
   289→- **FR-2.1**: System shall generate unique GUID identifiers for each session
   290→- **FR-2.2**: System shall store sessions in application memory only
   291→- **FR-2.3**: System shall expire sessions after 10 minutes of inactivity
   292→- **FR-2.4**: System shall support maximum 16 users per session
   293→- **FR-2.5**: System shall provide session discovery interface showing active sessions
   294→- **FR-2.6**: System shall generate shareable session links in format `/session/{GUID}`
   295→
   296→### 5.3 Role Management
   297→- **FR-3.1**: System shall assign Scrum Master role to session creator
   298→- **FR-3.2**: System shall allow Scrum Master to transfer role to any session participant
   299→- **FR-3.3**: System shall allow Scrum Master to remove users from session
   300→- **FR-3.4**: System shall pause session when Scrum Master disconnects
   301→- **FR-3.5**: System shall auto-assign Scrum Master role after 5-minute timeout
   302→
   303→### 5.4 Voting System
   304→- **FR-4.1**: System shall provide Fibonacci voting cards: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, Coffee
   305→- **FR-4.2**: System shall hide individual votes until Scrum Master reveals them
   306→- **FR-4.3**: System shall allow vote changes until revelation
   307→- **FR-4.4**: System shall calculate and display vote statistics (average, distribution)
   308→- **FR-4.5**: System shall support multiple voting rounds per session
   309→- **FR-4.6**: System shall reset voting state when new round starts
   310→
   311→### 5.5 Real-time Communication
   312→- **FR-5.1**: System shall provide real-time updates using WebSocket or similar protocol
   313→- **FR-5.2**: System shall synchronize all user actions across clients within 1 second
   314→- **FR-5.3**: System shall handle connection drops and automatic reconnection
   315→- **FR-5.4**: System shall maintain session state during user disconnections
   316→
   317→### 5.6 User Interface
   318→- **FR-6.1**: System shall display users as avatars around oval table layout
   319→- **FR-6.2**: System shall show voting status indicators for each user
   320→- **FR-6.3**: System shall provide responsive design for desktop, tablet, and mobile
   321→- **FR-6.4**: System shall display session timer showing time remaining before expiry
   322→- **FR-6.5**: System shall provide audio notifications for voting events
   323→
   324→---
   325→
   326→## 6. Non-Functional Requirements
   327→
   328→### 6.1 Performance
   329→- **NFR-1.1**: Application shall support maximum 3 concurrent sessions
   330→- **NFR-1.2**: Real-time updates shall have <1 second latency
   331→- **NFR-1.3**: Application shall handle 48 concurrent users (3 sessions × 16 users)
   332→- **NFR-1.4**: Session state changes shall propagate to all clients within 1 second
   333→
   334→### 6.2 Reliability
   335→- **NFR-2.1**: Application shall have 99% uptime during business hours
   336→- **NFR-2.2**: System shall gracefully handle user disconnections
   337→- **NFR-2.3**: Application shall recover from temporary network issues automatically
   338→
   339→### 6.3 Usability
   340→- **NFR-3.1**: Application shall be intuitive enough for first-time users without training
   341→- **NFR-3.2**: Critical user actions shall be completed in ≤3 clicks
   342→- **NFR-3.3**: Application shall provide clear visual feedback for all user actions
   343→- **NFR-3.4**: Error messages shall be user-friendly and actionable
   344→
   345→### 6.4 Compatibility
   346→- **NFR-4.1**: Application shall support Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari (current versions)
   347→- **NFR-4.2**: Application shall work on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices
   348→- **NFR-4.3**: Application shall function without requiring plugins or extensions
   349→
   350→### 6.5 Security
   351→- **NFR-5.1**: Application shall validate all user inputs to prevent injection attacks
   352→- **NFR-5.2**: Session data shall be contained within application memory only
   353→- **NFR-5.3**: No persistent storage of user data beyond browser cookies
   354→
   355→---
   356→
   357→## 7. Technical Requirements
   358→
   359→### 7.1 System Components
   360→- **Backend**: Web API service with RESTful endpoints
   361→- **Frontend**: Web application with responsive design
   362→- **Real-time Communication**: WebSocket-based real-time updates
   363→- **Data Storage**: In-memory session storage (no persistent database)
   364→- **Hosting**: Web server in corporate environment
   365→
   366→### 7.2 Architecture Requirements
   367→- **TR-1.1**: RESTful API design for HTTP endpoints
   368→- **TR-1.2**: Real-time communication channels for live updates
   369→- **TR-1.3**: Stateless backend with session data in memory
   370→- **TR-1.4**: Single Page Application (SPA) architecture
   371→
   372→### 7.3 Data Requirements
   373→- **TR-2.1**: Session data stored in application memory with automatic cleanup
   374→- **TR-2.2**: User preferences stored in browser cookies only
   375→- **TR-2.3**: No persistent data storage required
   376→- **TR-2.4**: Session timeout configurable (default 10 minutes)
   377→
   378→---
   379→
   380→## 8. User Experience Requirements
   381→
   382→### 8.1 User Interface Design
   383→- Clean, modern interface with consistent design system
   384→- Responsive grid layout and utilities
   385→- Oval table visualization for virtual boardroom
   386→- Intuitive voting card interface with visual feedback
   387→- Clear status indicators and progress feedback
   388→
   389→### 8.2 User Journey Flow
   390→1. **Entry**: User enters name/avatar or uses saved settings
   391→2. **Session Selection**: User creates new session or joins existing
   392→3. **Boardroom**: User sees virtual table with all participants
   393→4. **Voting**: Scrum Master starts round, users submit votes
   394→5. **Results**: Scrum Master reveals votes, team sees statistics
   395→6. **Iteration**: Multiple rounds as needed
   396→7. **Conclusion**: Scrum Master ends session
   397→
   398→### 8.3 Accessibility Requirements
   399→- Keyboard navigation support
   400→- Screen reader compatibility for essential functions
   401→- High contrast mode compatibility
   402→- Light/Dark mode option
   403→- Mobile touch interface optimization
   404→
   405→---
   406→
   407→## 9. Success Metrics & KPIs
   408→
   409→### 9.1 Usage Metrics
   410→- Number of sessions created per week
   411→- Average session duration
   412→- Average number of voting rounds per session
   413→- User retention rate within sessions
   414→
   415→### 9.2 Performance Metrics
   416→- Page load time <2 seconds
   417→- Real-time update latency <1 second
   418→- Connection success rate >98%
   419→- Session completion rate >95%
   420→
   421→### 9.3 Quality Metrics
   422→- User-reported issues per session <0.1
   423→- Successful reconnection rate >95%
   424→- Cross-browser compatibility issues <1%
   425→
   426→---
   427→
   428→## 10. Risk Assessment & Mitigation
   429→
   430→### 10.1 Technical Risks
   431→- **Risk**: WebSocket connection instability
   432→- **Mitigation**: Implement robust reconnection logic with exponential backoff
   433→
   434→- **Risk**: Memory leaks from session storage
   435→- **Mitigation**: Implement automatic cleanup and monitoring
   436→
   437→### 10.2 User Experience Risks
   438→- **Risk**: Poor mobile experience
   439→- **Mitigation**: Mobile-first responsive design and testing
   440→
   441→- **Risk**: Confusing voting interface
   442→- **Mitigation**: User testing and iterative UI improvements
   443→
   444→---
   445→
   446→## 11. Development Phases & Priorities
   447→
   448→### Phase 1: Core Foundation (MVP)
   449→- User registration and session creation
   450→- Basic boardroom visualization
   451→- Simple voting functionality
   452→- Session management
   453→
   454→### Phase 2: Enhanced Experience
   455→- Real-time synchronization improvements
   456→- Advanced UI/UX features
   457→- Mobile optimization
   458→- Audio notifications
   459→
   460→### Phase 3: Polish & Optimization
   461→- Performance optimization
   462→- Advanced statistics
   463→- Error handling improvements
   464→- Accessibility features
   465→
   466→---
   467→
   468→This PRD provides comprehensive detail for development planning while maintaining clarity for implementation. Each user story includes specific acceptance criteria that can be directly translated into development tasks and test cases for the MagnaPP application.

# Product Requirements Document (PRD)
## MagnaPP Web Application

---

## 1. Introduction & Overview

### 1.1 Product Name
**MagnaPP** (Agile Planning Poker Platform)

### 1.2 Problem Statement
Distributed agile development teams need an effective way to conduct Planning Poker estimation sessions remotely. Current solutions often lack real-time collaboration features or provide poor user experiences that hinder the estimation process.

### 1.3 Solution Overview
MagnaPP is a web-based Planning Poker application that enables multiple users to participate in real-time estimation sessions through a virtual boardroom interface. The application provides seamless collaboration with immediate visual feedback, session management, and reconnection capabilities.

### 1.4 Success Vision
Teams can easily create and join MagnaPP sessions, conduct multiple estimation rounds efficiently, and maintain engagement through an intuitive virtual boardroom experience.

---

## 2. Goals & Objectives

### 2.1 Primary Goals
- Enable real-time collaborative Planning Poker sessions for up to 16 users
- Provide an intuitive virtual boardroom experience that mimics in-person sessions
- Ensure seamless user experience across desktop and mobile devices
- Minimize setup time and technical barriers for users

### 2.2 Success Metrics
- Session completion rate: >95% of started sessions complete at least one voting round
- User retention: Users who join a session stay for the full duration >90% of the time
- Reconnection success: >98% of disconnected users successfully rejoin their session
- Cross-device functionality: Application works seamlessly on desktop and mobile

---

## 3. Target Audience & User Personas

### 3.1 Primary Users
**Agile Development Teams** (3-16 members)
- Scrum Masters, Product Owners, Developers, QA Engineers
- Teams working remotely or in hybrid environments
- Organizations using agile methodologies (Scrum, SAFe, etc.)

### 3.2 User Personas

#### Persona 1: Sarah - Scrum Master
- **Role**: Facilitates MagnaPP sessions
- **Goals**: Run efficient estimation sessions, maintain team engagement, keep discussions focused
- **Pain Points**: Coordinating remote team members, ensuring everyone participates
- **Technical Comfort**: High

#### Persona 2: Mike - Developer
- **Role**: Participates in estimation sessions
- **Goals**: Provide accurate estimates, understand story requirements
- **Pain Points**: Connection issues disrupting flow, unclear voting status
- **Technical Comfort**: High

#### Persona 3: Lisa - Product Owner
- **Role**: Participates in estimation, provides clarification
- **Goals**: Ensure team understands requirements, get reliable estimates
- **Pain Points**: Difficulty seeing who has voted, losing session context
- **Technical Comfort**: Medium

---

## 4. User Stories & Use Cases

### 4.1 Epic 1: User Registration & Session Access

#### User Story 1.1: Initial User Setup
**As a** new user  
**I want to** enter my name/alias and choose an avatar  
**So that** I can be identified in MagnaPP sessions  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- User must enter a name/alias (minimum 2 characters, maximum 50 characters)
- User can select from available icon library for avatar
- User settings are stored in browser local storage
- Settings persist across browser sessions
- Name validation prevents empty, whitespace-only, or special character names

#### User Story 1.2: Session Creation
**As a** Scrum Master  
**I want to** create a new MagnaPP session  
**So that** my team can join and participate in estimation  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- User can enter session name (required, 3-100 characters)
- System generates unique GUID for session ID
- System provides shareable link for the session
- User becomes Scrum Master with full session control
- Session is created in application memory
- Session expiry timer starts at 10 minutes of inactivity

#### User Story 1.3: Session Discovery
**As a** user  
**I want to** browse existing active sessions  
**So that** I can join a session without needing a direct link  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Display list of active sessions with names only
- Show sessions sorted by creation time (newest first)
- Allow user to select and join any active session
- Update list dynamically as sessions are created/expire
- Handle empty state when no sessions exist

#### User Story 1.4: Direct Session Joining
**As a** team member  
**I want to** join a session using a shared link  
**So that** I can quickly access the MagnaPP session  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Link format: `/session/{GUID}`
- If user has saved settings, auto-populate name/avatar
- If no saved settings, prompt for name/alias entry before joining
- Validate session exists and is active
- Handle expired or invalid session links with appropriate error message
- Redirect to session boardroom upon successful join

### 4.2 Epic 2: Session Management

#### User Story 2.1: Scrum Master Controls
**As a** Scrum Master  
**I want to** control the MagnaPP session flow  
**So that** I can facilitate effective estimation discussions  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Can start a new voting round for all participants
- Can reveal all votes simultaneously
- Can start a new round (resets all votes and voting status)
- Can end the session (returns all users to home screen)
- Can kick users from the session
- Can transfer Scrum Master role to another participant
- All actions are immediately reflected to all session participants

#### User Story 2.2: Session Inactivity Management
**As a** system administrator  
**I want** sessions to expire after inactivity  
**So that** system resources are managed efficiently  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Session expires after 10 minutes of no user activity
- Warning timer appears when 2 minutes remain
- All users see the countdown timer
- Expired sessions are removed from memory
- Users in expired sessions are redirected to home screen
- Activity includes: voting, revealing votes, starting new rounds, user joins/leaves

#### User Story 2.3: Scrum Master Disconnection Handling
**As a** session participant  
**I want** the session to wait for Scrum Master reconnection  
**So that** we don't lose session control or progress  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- When Scrum Master disconnects, session enters "paused" state
- All participants see "Waiting for Scrum Master to return" message
- Session controls are disabled for all users
- Scrum Master can reconnect and resume session within timeout period
- If Scrum Master doesn't return within 5 minutes, longest-connected user becomes new Scrum Master
- Automatic role transfer is announced to all participants

### 4.3 Epic 3: Virtual Boardroom Experience

#### User Story 3.1: Boardroom Visualization
**As a** session participant  
**I want to** see all users arranged around a virtual table  
**So that** I have a familiar meeting room experience  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Users displayed as avatars around an oval table
- Maximum 16 user positions around the table
- Avatar shows icon selected by user
- Username displayed below avatar
- Users positioned randomly around table when joining
- Scrum Master has visual indicator (crown icon or similar)
- Responsive layout works on desktop, tablet, and mobile

#### User Story 3.2: Voting Status Indicators
**As a** session participant  
**I want to** see who has voted in the current round  
**So that** I know the voting progress without seeing actual votes  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Each user has a visual indicator showing voted/not voted status
- Green indicator for "has voted"
- Red indicator for "not voted" (only during active voting)
- No indicator when not in voting round
- Indicators update in real-time as users submit votes
- My own vote is visible to me but not to others until reveal

### 4.4 Epic 4: Voting Process

#### User Story 4.1: Voting Round Initiation
**As a** Scrum Master  
**I want to** start a voting round  
**So that** all team members can submit their estimates  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- "Start Voting" button visible only to Scrum Master
- Button disabled during active voting or when results are shown
- Clicking starts voting round for all participants
- All users immediately see voting cards interface
- Audio notification plays for all users when voting starts
- Voting status indicators reset for all users

#### User Story 4.2: Vote Submission
**As a** session participant  
**I want to** select my estimate using voting cards  
**So that** I can participate in the estimation process  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Voting cards display Fibonacci sequence: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21
- Additional "Coffee" card for break requests
- Cards are visually distinct and clickable
- Selected card is highlighted/emphasized
- Can change vote until Scrum Master reveals votes
- My vote appears next to my avatar (visible only to me)
- Audio feedback when card is selected
- Vote is immediately saved and status indicator updates

#### User Story 4.3: Vote Revelation
**As a** Scrum Master  
**I want to** reveal all votes simultaneously  
**So that** we can discuss estimates and reach consensus  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- "Reveal Votes" button visible only to Scrum Master
- Button enabled only when at least one vote is submitted
- All votes revealed simultaneously across all clients
- Vote cards "flip over" next to each user's avatar to show their vote
- Vote statistics panel appears showing average and distribution
- Audio notification plays when votes are revealed
- Voting cards interface is hidden during results display

#### User Story 4.4: Vote Statistics
**As a** session participant  
**I want to** see voting statistics after revelation  
**So that** I can understand the team's estimation consensus  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Display average of numeric votes (excluding Coffee votes)
- Show vote distribution (count of each vote value)
- Indicate consensus when all votes are identical
- Coffee votes counted separately
- Statistics update automatically when votes are revealed
- Visual representation (simple bar chart or similar) for distribution

### 4.5 Epic 5: Connection Management

#### User Story 5.1: User Reconnection
**As a** session participant  
**I want to** rejoin my session after losing connection  
**So that** I can continue participating without disruption  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- User can rejoin session using same name/avatar
- Rejoined user sees current session state (voting round, results, etc.)
- If voting in progress and user had voted, show their previous vote
- If voting in progress and user hadn't voted, allow them to vote
- Other participants see reconnection notification
- User resumes at their previous position around the table

#### User Story 5.2: Real-time Synchronization
**As a** session participant  
**I want** all session changes to appear immediately  
**So that** I have a seamless collaborative experience  

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All user actions sync in real-time (<1 second delay)
- Vote submissions immediately update voting indicators
- Scrum Master actions (start voting, reveal votes) appear instantly
- User joins/leaves reflect immediately in boardroom
- Session state maintained consistently across all clients
- Connection status visible to users (connected/reconnecting indicator)

---

## 5. Functional Requirements

### 5.1 User Management
- **FR-1.1**: System shall allow users to set name/alias (2-50 characters, alphanumeric and spaces only)
- **FR-1.2**: System shall provide icon selection for user avatars
- **FR-1.3**: System shall store user preferences in browser storage with 30-day expiration
- **FR-1.4**: System shall validate user input and provide appropriate error messages

### 5.2 Session Management
- **FR-2.1**: System shall generate unique GUID identifiers for each session
- **FR-2.2**: System shall store sessions in application memory only
- **FR-2.3**: System shall expire sessions after 10 minutes of inactivity
- **FR-2.4**: System shall support maximum 16 users per session
- **FR-2.5**: System shall provide session discovery interface showing active sessions
- **FR-2.6**: System shall generate shareable session links in format `/session/{GUID}`

### 5.3 Role Management
- **FR-3.1**: System shall assign Scrum Master role to session creator
- **FR-3.2**: System shall allow Scrum Master to transfer role to any session participant
- **FR-3.3**: System shall allow Scrum Master to remove users from session
- **FR-3.4**: System shall pause session when Scrum Master disconnects
- **FR-3.5**: System shall auto-assign Scrum Master role after 5-minute timeout

### 5.4 Voting System
- **FR-4.1**: System shall provide Fibonacci voting cards: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, Coffee
- **FR-4.2**: System shall hide individual votes until Scrum Master reveals them
- **FR-4.3**: System shall allow vote changes until revelation
- **FR-4.4**: System shall calculate and display vote statistics (average, distribution)
- **FR-4.5**: System shall support multiple voting rounds per session
- **FR-4.6**: System shall reset voting state when new round starts

### 5.5 Real-time Communication
- **FR-5.1**: System shall provide real-time updates using WebSocket or similar protocol
- **FR-5.2**: System shall synchronize all user actions across clients within 1 second
- **FR-5.3**: System shall handle connection drops and automatic reconnection
- **FR-5.4**: System shall maintain session state during user disconnections

### 5.6 User Interface
- **FR-6.1**: System shall display users as avatars around oval table layout
- **FR-6.2**: System shall show voting status indicators for each user
- **FR-6.3**: System shall provide responsive design for desktop, tablet, and mobile
- **FR-6.4**: System shall display session timer showing time remaining before expiry
- **FR-6.5**: System shall provide audio notifications for voting events

---

## 6. Non-Functional Requirements

### 6.1 Performance
- **NFR-1.1**: Application shall support maximum 3 concurrent sessions
- **NFR-1.2**: Real-time updates shall have <1 second latency
- **NFR-1.3**: Application shall handle 48 concurrent users (3 sessions × 16 users)
- **NFR-1.4**: Session state changes shall propagate to all clients within 1 second

### 6.2 Reliability
- **NFR-2.1**: Application shall have 99% uptime during business hours
- **NFR-2.2**: System shall gracefully handle user disconnections
- **NFR-2.3**: Application shall recover from temporary network issues automatically

### 6.3 Usability
- **NFR-3.1**: Application shall be intuitive enough for first-time users without training
- **NFR-3.2**: Critical user actions shall be completed in ≤3 clicks
- **NFR-3.3**: Application shall provide clear visual feedback for all user actions
- **NFR-3.4**: Error messages shall be user-friendly and actionable

### 6.4 Compatibility
- **NFR-4.1**: Application shall support Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari (current versions)
- **NFR-4.2**: Application shall work on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices
- **NFR-4.3**: Application shall function without requiring plugins or extensions

### 6.5 Security
- **NFR-5.1**: Application shall validate all user inputs to prevent injection attacks
- **NFR-5.2**: Session data shall be contained within application memory only
- **NFR-5.3**: No persistent storage of user data beyond browser cookies

---

## 7. Technical Requirements

### 7.1 System Components
- **Backend**: Web API service with RESTful endpoints
- **Frontend**: Web application with responsive design
- **Real-time Communication**: WebSocket-based real-time updates
- **Data Storage**: In-memory session storage (no persistent database)
- **Hosting**: Web server in corporate environment

### 7.2 Architecture Requirements
- **TR-1.1**: RESTful API design for HTTP endpoints
- **TR-1.2**: Real-time communication channels for live updates
- **TR-1.3**: Stateless backend with session data in memory
- **TR-1.4**: Single Page Application (SPA) architecture

### 7.3 Data Requirements
- **TR-2.1**: Session data stored in application memory with automatic cleanup
- **TR-2.2**: User preferences stored in browser cookies only
- **TR-2.3**: No persistent data storage required
- **TR-2.4**: Session timeout configurable (default 10 minutes)

---

## 8. User Experience Requirements

### 8.1 User Interface Design
- Clean, modern interface with consistent design system
- Responsive grid layout and utilities
- Oval table visualization for virtual boardroom
- Intuitive voting card interface with visual feedback
- Clear status indicators and progress feedback

### 8.2 User Journey Flow
1. **Entry**: User enters name/avatar or uses saved settings
2. **Session Selection**: User creates new session or joins existing
3. **Boardroom**: User sees virtual table with all participants
4. **Voting**: Scrum Master starts round, users submit votes
5. **Results**: Scrum Master reveals votes, team sees statistics
6. **Iteration**: Multiple rounds as needed
7. **Conclusion**: Scrum Master ends session

### 8.3 Accessibility Requirements
- Keyboard navigation support
- Screen reader compatibility for essential functions
- High contrast mode compatibility
- Light/Dark mode option
- Mobile touch interface optimization

---

## 9. Success Metrics & KPIs

### 9.1 Usage Metrics
- Number of sessions created per week
- Average session duration
- Average number of voting rounds per session
- User retention rate within sessions

### 9.2 Performance Metrics
- Page load time <2 seconds
- Real-time update latency <1 second
- Connection success rate >98%
- Session completion rate >95%

### 9.3 Quality Metrics
- User-reported issues per session <0.1
- Successful reconnection rate >95%
- Cross-browser compatibility issues <1%

---

## 10. Risk Assessment & Mitigation

### 10.1 Technical Risks
- **Risk**: WebSocket connection instability
- **Mitigation**: Implement robust reconnection logic with exponential backoff

- **Risk**: Memory leaks from session storage
- **Mitigation**: Implement automatic cleanup and monitoring

### 10.2 User Experience Risks
- **Risk**: Poor mobile experience
- **Mitigation**: Mobile-first responsive design and testing

- **Risk**: Confusing voting interface
- **Mitigation**: User testing and iterative UI improvements

---

## 11. Development Phases & Priorities

### Phase 1: Core Foundation (MVP)
- User registration and session creation
- Basic boardroom visualization
- Simple voting functionality
- Session management

### Phase 2: Enhanced Experience
- Real-time synchronization improvements
- Advanced UI/UX features
- Mobile optimization
- Audio notifications

### Phase 3: Polish & Optimization
- Performance optimization
- Advanced statistics
- Error handling improvements
- Accessibility features

---

This PRD provides comprehensive detail for development planning while maintaining clarity for implementation. Each user story includes specific acceptance criteria that can be directly translated into development tasks and test cases for the MagnaPP application.

content.text:
Based on the MagnaPP PRD, I can see this is a Planning Poker web application for agile teams. I need to clarify the technology stack with you before creating the task plan.

## STACK DECISION PROPOSAL

For this **web application** (Planning Poker for distributed agile teams), I need your input on the technology choices:

### Frontend Framework
Please choose one:
1. **React** with TypeScript - Component-based, large ecosystem, great for real-time updates
2. **Vue.js** with TypeScript - Progressive framework, excellent DX, simpler learning curve  
3. **Next.js** (React-based) - Full-stack capabilities, SSR/SSG support, built-in optimizations
4. **Angular** - Enterprise-ready, full framework with everything included
5. **Vanilla JS/TypeScript** - No framework dependencies, lightweight

What's your preference for the frontend framework?

Good choice! Next.js will give us full-stack capabilities with excellent TypeScript support and built-in optimizations.

Now let me ask about the **Backend/API** approach:

### Backend/API Strategy
Please choose one:
1. **Next.js API Routes** - Use Next.js built-in API routes (serverless functions) for the REST API
2. **Separate Node.js Backend** - Express/Fastify/NestJS as a dedicated API server
3. **Next.js + Socket.io Server** - Next.js for web + separate Socket.io server for WebSockets
4. **Next.js + Integrated WebSockets** - All-in-one with Next.js custom server

Given that we need WebSocket support for real-time updates (voting, user status, etc.), what's your preference?

Excellent! A Go backend will provide great performance for real-time operations and efficient memory management for our in-memory session storage.

Now let me ask about the **WebSocket/Real-time** approach for the Go backend:

### Real-time Communication Library
Please choose one:
1. **Gorilla WebSocket** - Popular, well-maintained WebSocket library for Go
2. **Melody** - Higher-level WebSocket framework built on Gorilla
3. **Centrifugo/Centrifuge** - Scalable real-time messaging server/library
4. **Native net/http with nhooyr/websocket** - Modern, minimal WebSocket library
5. **Socket.io-go** - Go implementation of Socket.io protocol (better Next.js client compatibility)

What's your preference for handling WebSockets in Go?

message.content: Let's drop golang and go with Next.js API Routes

content.text:
Perfect! Using Next.js API Routes will simplify our architecture significantly. 

Now for **WebSocket/Real-time** communication with Next.js:

### Real-time Communication Strategy
Please choose one:
1. **Socket.io** - Battle-tested, automatic fallbacks, reconnection handling, rooms support
2. **Pusher** - Managed WebSocket service, minimal backend code needed
3. **Server-Sent Events (SSE)** - One-way real-time updates, simpler than WebSockets
4. **Next.js with custom WebSocket server** - Using 'ws' library with Next.js custom server
5. **Polling** - Simple HTTP polling (not ideal but works everywhere)

Given we need bidirectional real-time updates for voting status and session management, what's your preference?

Excellent choice! Socket.io will handle our real-time requirements perfectly with automatic reconnection and room management for sessions.

Now let me ask about **Authentication/Session Management**:

### Auth & Session Strategy
Please choose one:
1. **Simple in-memory sessions** - No auth, just browser storage + session GUIDs (as PRD suggests)
2. **NextAuth.js** - Full auth solution (might be overkill for this use case)
3. **JWT tokens** - Stateless session tokens stored in browser
4. **Cookie-based sessions** - Server-side session management with cookies
5. **Local Storage only** - Client-side only, no server validation

Based on the PRD (no persistent database, simple name/avatar setup), what's your preference?

Perfect! That aligns well with the PRD requirements - simple and efficient.

Last question - **Testing Framework**:

### Testing Strategy
Please choose one:
1. **Jest + React Testing Library** - Standard Next.js testing setup for unit/integration tests
2. **Vitest + React Testing Library** - Faster alternative to Jest, Vite-powered
3. **Playwright** - E2E testing for real user flows (especially good for WebSocket testing)
4. **Cypress** - E2E testing with great DX and debugging
5. **Jest + RTL + Playwright** - Comprehensive testing (unit + E2E)

What's your preference for testing this real-time collaborative app?
Great! Now I have all the stack decisions. Let me create the project structure and task plan.

input.content:
# Technology Stack Decisions

## Date: 2025-08-21

### Frontend Framework
**Choice:** Next.js with TypeScript
**Rationale:** 
- Full-stack capabilities with API routes
- Built-in optimizations and performance features
- Excellent TypeScript support
- SSR/SSG capabilities for better initial load
- Large ecosystem and community support

### Backend/API
**Choice:** Next.js API Routes
**Rationale:**
- Simplified architecture (single deployment)
- Serverless functions scale automatically
- No need for separate backend service
- Reduced complexity in development and deployment

### Real-time Communication
**Choice:** Socket.io
**Rationale:**
- Battle-tested with automatic reconnection
- Built-in room management perfect for sessions
- Fallback mechanisms for unreliable connections
- Client/server library compatibility
- Handles our 16-user per session requirement easily

### Session Management
**Choice:** Simple in-memory sessions
**Rationale:**
- Aligns with PRD requirement (no persistent database)
- Session data stored in server memory
- Browser local storage for user preferences
- GUID-based session identification
- Simple and efficient for our use case

### Testing Framework
**Choice:** Jest + React Testing Library
**Rationale:**
- Standard Next.js testing setup
- Good for unit and integration testing
- Component testing capabilities
- Well-documented and widely adopted
- Can mock Socket.io connections for testing

## Architecture Overview
- **Frontend:** Next.js pages/components with TypeScript
- **API:** Next.js API routes for REST endpoints
- **WebSocket Server:** Socket.io server integrated with Next.js custom server
- **State Management:** React Context + Socket.io for real-time state
- **Styling:** Tailwind CSS for responsive design
- **Session Storage:** In-memory Map/Object with TTL management
- **User Preferences:** Browser localStorage

# Project Task Plan - MagnaPP Planning Poker

## Setup & Configuration
- [ ] Initialize Next.js project with TypeScript
- [ ] Create `.env.example` with required environment variables
- [ ] Configure ESLint and Prettier for code consistency
- [ ] Set up Jest and React Testing Library
- [ ] Create README with setup instructions
- [ ] Add .gitignore and .editorconfig files
- [ ] Set up Tailwind CSS for styling

## Project Structure
- [ ] Create folder structure (components, pages, lib, types, etc.)
- [ ] Set up Socket.io with Next.js custom server
- [ ] Create TypeScript interfaces for data models
- [ ] Set up shared constants and configuration

## Core Data Models & Types
- [ ] Define User interface (name, avatar, userId)
- [ ] Define Session interface (sessionId, name, users, scrumMaster)
- [ ] Define Vote interface and voting cards enum
- [ ] Define WebSocket event types
- [ ] Create session storage manager class

## Session Management (Backend)
- [ ] Implement in-memory session storage with Map
- [ ] Add session creation with GUID generation
- [ ] Implement session expiry (10-minute timeout)
- [ ] Add session cleanup on timeout
- [ ] Create session validation middleware
- [ ] Implement max sessions limit (3 concurrent)

## API Routes
- [ ] POST /api/sessions - Create new session
- [ ] GET /api/sessions - List active sessions
- [ ] GET /api/sessions/[id] - Get session details
- [ ] POST /api/sessions/[id]/join - Join session
- [ ] DELETE /api/sessions/[id] - End session
- [ ] PUT /api/sessions/[id]/transfer - Transfer Scrum Master role

## WebSocket Events (Socket.io)
- [ ] Set up Socket.io server with Next.js
- [ ] Implement connection/disconnection handlers

input.content:
# MagnaPP - Planning Poker Application

A real-time collaborative Planning Poker application for distributed agile teams.

## Features

- 🎯 Real-time Planning Poker sessions with up to 16 participants
- 🎮 Virtual boardroom with oval table visualization
- 🔄 Automatic reconnection and session recovery
- 📊 Instant voting statistics and consensus detection
- 👑 Scrum Master controls for session management
- 📱 Responsive design for desktop, tablet, and mobile

## Tech Stack

- **Frontend**: Next.js 15 with TypeScript
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS
- **Real-time**: Socket.io
- **Testing**: Jest + React Testing Library
- **Session Storage**: In-memory (no database required)

## Prerequisites

- Node.js 18+ 
- npm 9+

## Getting Started

### 1. Clone the repository

```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd planning-poker-magnapp
```

### 2. Install dependencies

```bash
npm install
```

### 3. Set up environment variables

Copy the sample environment file and adjust as needed:

```bash
cp .env.sample .env.local
```

### 4. Run the development server

```bash
npm run dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) to view the application.

## Available Scripts

- `npm run dev` - Start development server with hot-reload
- `npm run build` - Build production application
- `npm start` - Start production server
- `npm run lint` - Run ESLint
- `npm run format` - Format code with Prettier
- `npm test` - Run tests
- `npm run test:watch` - Run tests in watch mode
- `npm run test:coverage` - Generate test coverage report

## Project Structure

```
planning-poker-magnapp/
├── app/                    # Next.js app directory
│   ├── api/               # API routes
│   ├── session/           # Session pages
│   └── layout.tsx         # Root layout
├── components/            # React components
├── lib/                   # Utility functions and core logic
│   ├── socket/           # Socket.io configuration
│   ├── session/          # Session management
│   └── types/            # TypeScript types
├── public/               # Static assets
├── docs/                 # Documentation
└── plans/                # Task planning
```

## Configuration

See `.env.sample` for all available configuration options:

- `SESSION_TIMEOUT_MINUTES`: Session inactivity timeout (default: 10)
- `MAX_CONCURRENT_SESSIONS`: Maximum concurrent sessions (default: 3)
- `MAX_USERS_PER_SESSION`: Maximum users per session (default: 16)
- `SCRUM_MASTER_GRACE_PERIOD_MINUTES`: Grace period for Scrum Master reconnection (default: 5)

## Development

### Code Style

This project uses ESLint and Prettier for code formatting. Run `npm run format` before committing.

### Testing

Write tests for new features in the `__tests__` directories. Run `npm test` to execute the test suite.

### Commit Convention

Use conventional commits:
- `feat:` New features
- `fix:` Bug fixes
- `docs:` Documentation changes
- `style:` Code style changes

# MagnaPP - Planning Poker Application

A real-time collaborative Planning Poker application for distributed agile teams.

## Features

- 🎯 Real-time Planning Poker sessions with up to 16 participants
- 🎮 Virtual boardroom with oval table visualization
- 🔄 Automatic reconnection and session recovery
- 📊 Instant voting statistics and consensus detection
- 👑 Scrum Master controls for session management
- 📱 Responsive design for desktop, tablet, and mobile

## Tech Stack

- **Frontend**: Next.js 15 with TypeScript
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS
- **Real-time**: Socket.io
- **Testing**: Jest + React Testing Library
- **Session Storage**: In-memory (no database required)

## Prerequisites

- Node.js 18+ 
- npm 9+

## Getting Started

### 1. Clone the repository

```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd planning-poker-magnapp
```

### 2. Install dependencies

```bash
npm install
```

### 3. Set up environment variables

Copy the sample environment file and adjust as needed:

```bash
cp .env.sample .env.local
```

### 4. Run the development server

```bash
npm run dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) to view the application.

## Available Scripts

- `npm run dev` - Start development server with hot-reload
- `npm run build` - Build production application
- `npm start` - Start production server
- `npm run lint` - Run ESLint
- `npm run format` - Format code with Prettier
- `npm test` - Run tests
- `npm run test:watch` - Run tests in watch mode
- `npm run test:coverage` - Generate test coverage report

## Project Structure

```
planning-poker-magnapp/
├── app/                    # Next.js app directory
│   ├── api/               # API routes
│   ├── session/           # Session pages
│   └── layout.tsx         # Root layout
├── components/            # React components
├── lib/                   # Utility functions and core logic
│   ├── socket/           # Socket.io configuration
│   ├── session/          # Session management
│   └── types/            # TypeScript types
├── public/               # Static assets
├── docs/                 # Documentation
└── plans/                # Task planning
```

## Configuration

See `.env.sample` for all available configuration options:

- `SESSION_TIMEOUT_MINUTES`: Session inactivity timeout (default: 10)
- `MAX_CONCURRENT_SESSIONS`: Maximum concurrent sessions (default: 3)
- `MAX_USERS_PER_SESSION`: Maximum users per session (default: 16)
- `SCRUM_MASTER_GRACE_PERIOD_MINUTES`: Grace period for Scrum Master reconnection (default: 5)

## Development

### Code Style

This project uses ESLint and Prettier for code formatting. Run `npm run format` before committing.

### Testing

Write tests for new features in the `__tests__` directories. Run `npm test` to execute the test suite.

### Commit Convention

Use conventional commits:
- `feat:` New features
- `fix:` Bug fixes
- `docs:` Documentation changes
- `style:` Code style changes
- `refactor:` Code refactoring
- `test:` Test additions/changes
- `chore:` Build process or auxiliary tool changes

## License

[License Type] - See LICENSE file for details

## Support

For issues and feature requests, please use the GitHub issue tracker.

# Project Task Plan - MagnaPP Planning Poker

## Setup & Configuration
- [ ] Initialize Next.js project with TypeScript
- [ ] Create `.env.example` with required environment variables
- [ ] Configure ESLint and Prettier for code consistency
- [ ] Set up Jest and React Testing Library
- [ ] Create README with setup instructions
- [ ] Add .gitignore and .editorconfig files
- [ ] Set up Tailwind CSS for styling

## Project Structure
- [ ] Create folder structure (components, pages, lib, types, etc.)
- [ ] Set up Socket.io with Next.js custom server
- [ ] Create TypeScript interfaces for data models
- [ ] Set up shared constants and configuration

## Core Data Models & Types
- [ ] Define User interface (name, avatar, userId)
- [ ] Define Session interface (sessionId, name, users, scrumMaster)
- [ ] Define Vote interface and voting cards enum
- [ ] Define WebSocket event types
- [ ] Create session storage manager class

## Session Management (Backend)
- [ ] Implement in-memory session storage with Map
- [ ] Add session creation with GUID generation
- [ ] Implement session expiry (10-minute timeout)
- [ ] Add session cleanup on timeout
- [ ] Create session validation middleware
- [ ] Implement max sessions limit (3 concurrent)

## API Routes
- [ ] POST /api/sessions - Create new session
- [ ] GET /api/sessions - List active sessions
- [ ] GET /api/sessions/[id] - Get session details
- [ ] POST /api/sessions/[id]/join - Join session
- [ ] DELETE /api/sessions/[id] - End session
- [ ] PUT /api/sessions/[id]/transfer - Transfer Scrum Master role

## WebSocket Events (Socket.io)
- [ ] Set up Socket.io server with Next.js
- [ ] Implement connection/disconnection handlers
- [ ] Create room management for sessions
- [ ] Add user join/leave events
- [ ] Implement voting events (start, submit, reveal)
- [ ] Add Scrum Master control events
- [ ] Implement reconnection logic

## User Management
- [ ] Create user preferences storage (localStorage)
- [ ] Build name/avatar selection component
- [ ] Implement avatar icon library
- [ ] Add user validation (name length, characters)
- [ ] Create user context provider

## Home Page & Session Discovery
- [ ] Design and build home page layout
- [ ] Create session list component
- [ ] Add "Create Session" interface
- [ ] Implement join session by link
- [ ] Add user settings modal
- [ ] Handle empty states

## Virtual Boardroom UI
- [ ] Create boardroom layout with oval table
- [ ] Position user avatars around table (max 16)
- [ ] Add Scrum Master indicator
- [ ] Implement voting status indicators
- [ ] Create responsive layout for mobile/tablet
- [ ] Add session info header (name, timer)

## Voting Interface
- [ ] Create voting card components (Fibonacci + Coffee)
- [ ] Implement card selection interaction
- [ ] Add vote submission logic
- [ ] Create vote reveal animation
- [ ] Build statistics display component
- [ ] Add voting round management

## Scrum Master Controls
- [ ] Create control panel UI for Scrum Master
- [ ] Implement "Start Voting" functionality
- [ ] Add "Reveal Votes" functionality  
- [ ] Create "New Round" functionality
- [ ] Add user kick functionality
- [ ] Implement role transfer UI

## Real-time Synchronization
- [ ] Sync user joins/leaves across clients
- [ ] Implement real-time voting status updates
- [ ] Sync vote submissions
- [ ] Add real-time vote reveal
- [ ] Implement session state synchronization
- [ ] Add connection status indicator

## Session Timeout & Cleanup
- [ ] Implement activity tracking
- [ ] Add countdown timer display (last 2 minutes)
- [ ] Create timeout warning notifications
- [ ] Implement automatic session cleanup
- [ ] Handle expired session redirects

## Scrum Master Disconnection
- [ ] Detect Scrum Master disconnection
- [ ] Implement session pause state
- [ ] Add waiting message for participants
- [ ] Create 5-minute grace period timer
- [ ] Implement automatic role transfer logic

## Error Handling & Validation
- [ ] Add input validation for all forms
- [ ] Implement error boundaries
- [ ] Create user-friendly error messages
- [ ] Add WebSocket error handling
- [ ] Implement reconnection with exponential backoff

## Testing
- [ ] Write unit tests for session management
- [ ] Test WebSocket event handlers
- [ ] Add component tests for UI elements
- [ ] Test voting flow end-to-end
- [ ] Test reconnection scenarios
- [ ] Test session timeout behavior

## Performance & Optimization
- [ ] Optimize WebSocket message payloads
- [ ] Add debouncing for frequent updates
- [ ] Implement lazy loading for components
- [ ] Optimize avatar/icon loading
- [ ] Add performance monitoring hooks

## Accessibility & UX
- [ ] Add keyboard navigation support
- [ ] Implement ARIA labels
- [ ] Add focus management
- [ ] Create loading states
- [ ] Add sound effects toggle
- [ ] Implement light/dark mode

## Documentation & Deployment
- [ ] Write API documentation
- [ ] Create user guide
- [ ] Document WebSocket events
- [ ] Add deployment instructions
- [ ] Create environment setup guide
- [ ] Write troubleshooting guide
